title: How to Load & Use a Caulk Gun for the First Time

steps.title: Clean off all the old caulk with a putty knife.
steps.content: Clean off all the old caulk with a putty knife . Place the sharp end of the putty knife at the base of the old caulk. Then, grab the handle and push the knife forward. Keep pushing forward until you remove all the caulk . Alternatively, you can use a caulk removal tool or a utility knife. [1] X Expert Source Ryaan Tuttle Home Improvement Specialist Expert Interview. 13 January 2021. To make caulk easier to remove , apply a caulk softener , wait 20-30 minutes, and then scrape it with a carpet or putty knife. [2] X Expert Source Barry Zakar Handyman Expert Interview. 20 August 2020. By removing the old caulk that may be cracking, you're avoiding building a new layer on weak foundations. [3] X Expert Source Ryaan Tuttle Home Improvement Specialist Expert Interview. 13 January 2021.

steps.title: Wash the surface with alcohol, bleach, and hot water.
steps.content: Wash the surface with alcohol, bleach, and hot water. Wet a cloth with rubbing alcohol and set it on the crack to soften any leftover caulk. Then, wet a rag with warm water and diluted bleach to disinfect the surface. Then, rinse the area with a different rag soaked in hot water. [4] X Research source Dry the surface with a towel when you’re finished since new caulk won’t adhere when it’s wet. [5] X Research source Caulking traps anything inside the crack so make sure all dirt is completely removed. If you see any caulk or grime left over, use a plastic scraper to lift it up. If you're removing silicone caulk from tiles, heat it up with a hair dryer or apply a commercial solvent.

steps.title: Protect the surrounding surface with painter's tape.
steps.content: Protect the surrounding surface with painter's tape . Stick one long strip above the crack and one right below it. This tape keeps the caulk off of anything nearby so it doesn’t stick or harden where you don’t want it. It also acts as insurance in case you make a mistake later on. [6] X Research source Using painter's tape also makes the edges of your caulk line clean and smooth.

steps.title: Press the caulk gun’s release trigger to pull the rod back.
steps.content: Press the caulk gun’s release trigger to pull the rod back. Look for a small metal trigger on the back of the caulking gun where the long metal rod connects. Press the trigger down with your thumb to loosen the rod that runs through the entirety of the frame. With your other hand, pull the rod as far back as you can and hold it. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Cut the nozzle on a tube of caulk to a 45-degree angle.
steps.content: Cut the nozzle on a tube of caulk to a 45-degree angle. Use a pair of s cissors to cut the nozzle so it’s about the size of the crack. If the crack is large, consider cutting the nozzle close to the tube so more caulk comes out. If the crack is small, cut the nozzle near the end to be more precise. [8] X Research source This choice is permanent, so think carefully about the thickness before you make the cut. It's better to start closer to the end of the nozzle and make the opening bigger if you need to. [9] X Expert Source Barry Zakar Handyman Expert Interview. 20 August 2020.

steps.title: Pierce the nozzle with the gun’s piercing rod or a nail.
steps.content: Pierce the nozzle with the gun’s piercing rod or a nail. Check the front of the caulk gun for a short metal piece that folds out. Stick the metal piece into the end of the caulk’s nozzle until you feel it poke through the tube. If your caulk gun doesn’t have a small metal rod, then use a sharp nail to puncture the tube . [10] X Research source Check the instructions that came with the tube of caulk you’re using to see if there’s a specific way to pierce the tube.

steps.title: Insert the tube of caulk into the gun.
steps.content: Insert the tube of caulk into the gun. Keep holding the steel rod back, and put the flat end of the caulk tube into the back of the frame. Position the nozzle so it slots into the hole at the front of the gun. Squeeze the large trigger on the gun lightly to make sure the tube is snug and level. [11] X Research source If you need to, ask a friend or family member to help keep the rod back as you work on inserting the caulking tube.

steps.title: Pull the trigger and move the gun over a piece of paper to practice.
steps.content: Pull the trigger and move the gun over a piece of paper to practice. Hold the gun at a 45-degree angle with the nozzle facing downwards. Then, over a piece of paper, press the trigger at the back of the gun while moving the caulking gun steadily in one direction. The caulk will come out in a smooth, steady stream when you do it correctly. [12] X Research source If you move the caulking gun too fast, the caulk will look too thin and uneven. If you move the caulking gun too slowly, the caulk will be clumpy and unworkable. Take your time to find a good balance between the two. [13] X Expert Source Barry Zakar Handyman Expert Interview. 20 August 2020. It may take a few squeezes of the trigger to get your caulk gun started for the first time. Just let the pressure off the trigger and try squeezing it again.

steps.title: Hold the caulking gun at 45 degrees to the crack.
steps.content: Hold the caulking gun at 45 degrees to the crack. Hold the caulking gun with both hands so one is on the trigger and the other is supporting the end of the gun. Tilt the entire gun at a 45-degree angle so the caulk flows out evenly. [14] X Research source The caulk should start to flow towards the nozzle. [15] X Trustworthy Source U.S. Department of Energy Official site for the U.S. Department of Energy, which provides resources related to energy safety, conservation, and efficiency Go to source Although the trigger will push some of the caulk out of the tube, by holding the gun at 45 degrees, gravity helps with the process.

steps.title: Press the trigger to push the caulk into the nozzle.
steps.content: Press the trigger to push the caulk into the nozzle. Once you push the trigger, the steel rod will push the back of the caulk tube to force it out of the nozzle. Press the trigger firmly and steadily to apply the caulk in a slow, controlled manner. [16] X Expert Source Barry Zakar Handyman Expert Interview. 20 August 2020.

steps.title: Move the caulking gun across the length of the crack.
steps.content: Move the caulking gun across the length of the crack. As the caulk comes out of the nozzle, slowly move the caulking gun along the entire crack. Try to move in a single, steady motion so the caulk fills the crack evenly. [17] X Expert Source Barry Zakar Handyman Expert Interview. 20 August 2020. If you missed any spots, don't worry. Just come back and fill them in with a second pass.

steps.title: Smooth the caulk line with your finger.
steps.content: Smooth the caulk line with your finger. Put on a disposable glove and wet the tip of your finger with some warm water. Quickly drag your finger along the line of caulk to smooth it against the surface and create a clean finish. [18] X Expert Source Barry Zakar Handyman Expert Interview. 20 August 2020. Wearing a glove helps prevent caulk from sticking to your hands since it can be difficult to clean off.

steps.title: Remove any painter's tape and let the caulk dry.
steps.content: Remove any painter's tape and let the caulk dry. Peel off all the painter's tape and leave the caulk to dry. Each caulk tube will direct you with the precise time to wait until it's completely dry. Generally, it takes at least 24 hours for the caulk to completely solidify. [19] X Research source
